Award.AbstractNarration:
Methods from mathematical analysis have found wide applications in understanding physical phenomena in the natural sciences and engineering. This project is concerned with topics in harmonic analysis that are designed to provide effective mathematical tools for these disciplines and that could well contribute to the unification of seemingly unrelated areas. The main goal of the project is to expand the mathematical toolbox in harmonic analysis along these lines. The project involves mentoring of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers.

The principal investigator will to work on several projects in harmonic analysis. The first project is concerned with the functional calculus for selfadjoint elliptic and subelliptic partial differential operators. The research will focus on a model example in the subelliptic case, the Laplacian on the Heisenberg group. The goal is to derive new multiplier results on Lebesgue spaces, in particular for the model case of Bochner-Riesz means. In the Euclidean case such multiplier results can be based on Fourier restriction theory, which is not available on the Heisenberg group. A new approach is proposed based on the fine structure of the wave kernel on the Heisenberg group. A second project is motivated by a problem on the cost of mixing for incompressible flows that are generated by time-dependent vector fields. It turns out that this problem is related to boundedness questions on certain bilinear singular integral operators. A general theory will be developed that incorporates multilinear generalizations and is of independent interest. A third project is concerned with problems in approximation theory that involve function spaces of low order of smoothness. In many cases there are gaps between the known results for the categories of Besov and Sobolev spaces. As an example, the range for unconditional convergence of Haar wavelet expansions is well understood for Besov spaces but remains open for Sobolev spaces. One goal for this project is to determine the correct range for Sobolev spaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant funded research  by the principal investigator and his collaborators  and students in the mathematical area of harmonic analysis. 

One of the projects was motivated by a problem on the cost of mixing for incompressible flows that are generated by time-dependent vector fields. The problem is closely related to  boundedness questions on a family of bilinear singular integral operators. Jointly with Smart and Street a general theory was developed  that incorporates multilinear generalizations and is of independent interest. The work resulted in  new estimates for the mixing problem which involve Hardy spaces. This was joint work with Hadzic, Street and Smart. 


A second project dealt with the Fourier restriction problem for families of set with fractal dimensions. The PI, jointly with his former graduate student Xianghong  Chen,  obtained new estimates for families of Salem measures which are defined probabilistically.  They proved that the ranges for the restriction estimate may  be larger than previously predicted by the known examples.

In a third  project the PI and his former graduate student Jongchon Kim settled one of the  conjectures on strong summability almost everywhere for Bochner-Riesz means in an endpoint situation.


A fourth   project was concerned with questions from approximation theory that involve function spaces of low order of smoothness, in particular questions about the Haar wavelet system and its basis property  in function spaces. The PI, jointly with Ullrich, published  papers determining precisely the range for the  unconditional basis property in Sobolev spaces. Moreover,  in joint work with Garrigós and Ullrich, we  settled various questions on the Schauder basis property in the scales of Besov and Triebel-Lizorkin spaces. These questions were particularly interesting for various endpoint ranges, with different and unexpected  outcomes for the two scales.

The PI also worked on other problems arising in the theory of function spaces. In joint work with Trebels,  new embedding results were established for spaces of Lorentz-Sobolev type. Finally, joint work with Cufí, Nicolau, and Verdera resulted in a new  characterization of Sobolev spaces by square functions with independent increments and new results  for pointwise differentiation  for functions in the Zygmund class.

The grant also had an educational mission, supporting the research and education  of graduate students working in harmonic analysis. Several of the students supported under this grant graduated with a Ph.D. and continued their research as postdoctoral fellows at renowned universities and institutes.
